title: Which one is correct, 'fill in a form' or 'fill out a form'? - Quora
tags: Which Is Correct: X or Y?

response.answer_text: Hi, Arthur. Thanks for your question. You know, when I am busy with a form I have no idea whether I am filling that form in or out. However, should I talk to myself when I am going to bedazzle that form with my ‘beautiful’ handwriting I think of it as ‘I am going to fill that form in.’ while I am filling that form in, it would make sense to me to say to me that I am filling the form out as it has that correct sound. Let’s see what the clever guys have to say. Well, Arthur, whatever your little voice tells you have now arrived at the moment of truth. Are you ready for it? Well, ready or not; here it comes: Tadadada! “These expressions are very commonly confused by Malaysians. I’ve even seen a sign in a bank with this mistake. I’ll provide the definitions of each of these terms (from Wiktionary): Fill in – (transitive) to complete a form or questionnaire with requested information. Fill out – (transitive) to complete a form or questionnaire with requested information. Fill up– 1. (chiefly of a fuel tank) to make full. 2. to become full So we see that “fill in” and “fill out” mean to complete a questionnaire, survey or form with the necessary information. “Fill up” means to make something full, generally with a liquid. As mentioned by the dictionary, it is often used to refer to a car’s fuel tank. For example “I need to fill up my car”. “Fill up” CANNOT be used to mean “complete a form”. This is wrong. Can a form hold liquid? (Well, possibly if you rolled it into a cone it could, but then it would be ruined). Since it cannot hold liquid, it is not appropriate to use “fill up”. The appropriate expression to use with a form is “fill in” or “fill out” (even though “in” and “out” are opposites, “fill in” and “fill out” both have the same meaning). So please don’t ask anyone to “fill up a form” because they will not be able to do it. Ask them to “fill in” a form or “fill out” a form.” So, my man, what do you say? Am I not the cleverest? I was right on two occasions when I walked up to the form and while I filled in the form. Furthermore, I was not wrong to fill up the form. Give me a high five. You were in doubt so that does not count. Don’t worry, I’ve also made a mistake once. I thought I was wrong, but then it turned out I was right all along. Kind regards, Bye.

In American English, they are used interchangeably, but in British English, generally ‘fill in a form’ is used, the verb ‘fill out’ meaning ‘to expand’, in the sense of putting on weight, but rarely in the sense of completing a form.  Fill out a form, fill out a form? You mean ‘fill in a form’? Has everyone turned American? The term ‘fill out’ is used in American English because of German influence, as in German, you would say ich füllte das Formular aus or ‘I filled the form out’ which was translated directly by German speakers from their native language.  The Atlantic Reporter, Volumes 73-74, West Publishing Company, 1909, page 737 In German, the verb ‘to fill in’, ausfüllen, is a separable verb, hence aus or ‘out’ being used at the end of a sentence, but American English speakers may also talk about someone who ‘filled out the form’.  Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees Journal, Volume 48, 1939, page 11 In British English, it is more common to say that someone ‘filled in the form’, rather than ‘filled the form in’, but in Dutch, the verb ‘to fill in’ is invullen, hence ik vulde het formulier in or ‘I filled the form in’.  Joint Volumes of Papers Presented to the Legislative Council and Legislative Assembly, Volume 2, New South Wales. Parliament, 1907, page 289 This German influence also applies to some American English expressions that British English speakers love to hate, like ‘can I get…?’ which is similar to the German kann ich… bekommen? used instead of ‘may I have?’
